statements.name: PROC STANDARD
statements.description: Standardizes variables in a SAS data set to a given mean and standard deviation, and it creates a new SAS data set containing the standardized values.
statements.help:
PROC STANDARD 
            <options>;                   
	ATTRIB   variable-list(s) 
               attribute-list(s);
            
	BY 
               <DESCENDING>
               variable-1
		<… <DESCENDING> variable-n>
               
		<NOTSORTED>;
            
            
	FREQ 
               variable;
            
	FORMAT 
               variable-1
               < ...variable-n>
               <format>
               <DEFAULT=default-format>;
            
	LABEL 
               variable-1=label-1< ...variable-n=label-n>;
            
	VAR 
               variable(s);
            
	WEIGHT 
               variable;
            
	WHERE 
               where-expression-1
		
               <logical-operator where-expression-n>;

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set.

arguments.name: EXCLNPWGT
arguments.description: excludes observations with nonpositive weights.

arguments.name: MEAN=
arguments.description: specifies the mean value.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: suppresses all printed output.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set.

arguments.name: PRESERVERAWBYVALUES
arguments.description: preserves raw by values.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: prints statistics for each variable to standardize.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: replace missing values with a variable mean or MEAN= value.

arguments.name: STD=
arguments.description: specifies the standard deviation value.

arguments.name: VARDEF=
arguments.description: specifies the divisor for variance calculations and standard deviation. The following are choices are possible values for divisor and the associated divisors.

arguments.name: DF
arguments.description: degrees of freedom. The formula for divisor is n − 1.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: number of observations. The formula for divisor is n.

arguments.name: WDF
arguments.description: sum of weights minus one. The formula for divisor is (Σi wi) − 1.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: sum of weights. The formula for divisor is Σi wi.

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Associates a format, informat, label, and length with one or more variables.

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: names the variables that you want to associate with the attributes.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: INFORMAT=
arguments.description: associates an informat with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE=
arguments.description: specifies whether character variables can be transcoded. Use TRANSCODE=NO to suppress transcoding. Variables with TRANSCODE=NO are not returned.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Orders the output according to the BY groups.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variable that the procedure uses to form BY groups. You can specify more than one variable. If you do not use the NOTSORTED option in the BY statement, then either the observations in the data set must be sorted by all the variables that you specify, or they must be indexed appropriately. Variables in a BY statement are called BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order. The observations are grouped in another way (for example, chronological order).

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names one or more variables for SAS to associate with a format. You must specify at least one variable.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies the format that is listed for writing the values of the variables.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: Treats observations as if they appear multiple times in the input data set. You can use a WEIGHT statement and a FREQ statement in the same step of any procedure that supports both statements.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies a numeric variable whose value represents the frequency of the observation. If you use the FREQ statement, then the procedure assumes that each observation represents

arguments.name: text-string
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 bytes.
removes a label from a variable. Enclose a single blank space in quotation marks to remove an existing label. You can remove labels from multiple variables in a single LABEL statement:

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: Specifies the variables to standardize and their order in the printed output.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: identifies one or more variables to standardize.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: Specifies weights for analysis variables in the statistical calculations.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies a numeric variable whose values weight the values of the analysis variables. The values of the variable do not have to be integers. The table below shows what the action will be based on the weight value.

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Subsets the input data set by specifying certain conditions that each observation must meet before it is available for processing.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that generally consists of a sequence of operands and operators.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.
